Graphical abstract New bimetallic calcium–actinide (Th and U) oxides were synthesized and tested as catalysts for the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) using nitrous oxide as oxidant. The reaction main products were primarily C2 hydrocarbons (C2H4 and C2H6), particularly over the bimetallic calcium–thorium oxide catalyst (CH4 conversion≈28%; C2 selectivity≈53%; C2 yield≈15% at 800°C). The selectivity to hydrocarbons is promoted when thorium replaces uranium on the bimetallic calcium–actinide oxides (at CH4 isoconversion=15±3%; C2 selectivity≈32% and 64% over the bimetallic Ca–U–O and Ca–Th–O catalysts at 750°C, respectively), which can be linked to the actinide oxide phase properties. The bimetallic calcium–actinide oxides catalytic performance correlates with their acid–base and conductivity properties (selectivity to hydrocarbons increases with the catalysts basicity and it is higher over p-type conductors, e.g. ThO2). The influence of the reaction temperature, gas phase CH4/N2O molar ratio and type of oxidant agent were also studied. In particular, the studies performed either under O2 or N2O confirm that the use of nitrous oxide improves the selectivity to hydrocarbons. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time that an OCM study using N2O as oxidant agent is reported over bimetallic Ca–An (An=Th and U) oxides aiming the production of C2 hydrocarbons. Keywords Bimetallic calcium–actinide (Th, U) oxides OCM N2O Hydrocarbons 1 Introduction Nitrous oxide is recognized as a major greenhouse agent. In 2011, nitrous oxide (N2O) accounted for about 5% of all U.S. greenhouse gas emissions from human activities such as agriculture, fossil fuel combustion, wastewater management and industrial processes. About 20% of total N2O U.S. emissions come from transportation (5%), stationary combustion (6%) and industry or chemical production (9%) [1]. In Europe the situation is comparable but, the industrial contribution is higher. In 1994, about 38% of total N2O EU emissions come from transportation (5%), stationary combustion (3%) and industry or chemical production (30%) [2]. Industrial nitrous oxide (N2O) emissions are generated as a by-product during the production of adipic acid and nitric acid, but all major adipic acid producers have implemented N2O abatement technologies and as a result, nitric acid production is currently the largest industrial source of N2O emissions [3]. Nevertheless, due to the relatively “low N2O emissions” compared to the global demand for C2 hydrocarbons (especially ethylene), the main target of this study is the development of an added value environmental solution for the N2O produced either during stationary combustion (3–6%) or from industry or chemical (9–30%) sources. Alkaline earth and rare earth oxides are among the most intensively studied and effective catalysts for the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM), but the great majority of such studies were carried out using oxygen as oxidant [4–6]. Several aspects of this reaction continue to raise interesting questions from either a practical or theoretical point of view but OCM, using oxygen as oxidant, is already exploited as a viable alternative for higher hydrocarbons production [4,5,7–9]. However, few studies have been reported for the oxidative coupling of lower alkanes with N2O [10,11] and, for the reported cases, the rate of methane conversion and the selectivity to C2 hydrocarbons needs to be improved and the operating temperature lowered in order to become a process with industrial application (or economically viable) [9,12,13]. Among the existing works, the ones by Kondratenko and co-workers [11,14,15] which studied the potential of substituting O2 by N2O, for the oxidative coupling of methane should be mentioned due to the importance of their results. Concerning the use of N2O as oxidant it should be emphasized that its use allows the formation of more selective and mobile surface oxygen species [13,16], which is a critical point to the catalysts behavior. In addition, it is known that OCM most important step involves the abstraction of hydrogen from methane and production of CH3 radicals, yielding the formation of higher hydrocarbons [17–20]. However, the nature and the mechanism at the active sites are not clear yet. Mechanistic studies have identified different oxygen species as active sites for methane activation, namely: molecular species such as O2 − [20,21], O2 2− for lanthanide oxides [20,22,23]; dissociated oxygen species such as ions O− [17,18,24,25] or nucleophile ions O2− of the catalyst lattice for alkaline earth oxides [26]. The importance of the nature of these oxygen species is indirectly supported by the results of the OCM reaction when different oxidizing agents were used. Kondratenko's work with N2O as oxidant for methane studied the type of oxygen species formed on the surface and established that the replacement of O2 by N2O lead to an increase on the selectivity and activity through the formation of C2 hydrocarbons at similar conversions of both oxidants. He also showed that the surface structure and the type of oxygen species, including their evolution during the catalytic reaction, could be determinant for the catalyst behavior [11,14,15]. Also many physical and physicochemical properties of metal oxides, such as basicity and acidity, surface morphology, band gap and electrical conductivity (i.e., n- and/or p-type conductivity) can affect the catalysts performance [27–29]. Catalyst basicity has been found to be a key factor in determining their activity and selectivity to hydrocarbons and good catalytic performance has been correlated to the existence of strong basic sites [9,30,31]. The combination of alkaline earth and lanthanide oxides proved to be effective to obtain efficient OCM catalysts [32–34], but the work covering actinides is scarce. The few ones that can be found in the literature describes only the behavior of thorium or uranium oxides based catalysts using molecular oxygen as oxidant agent [35–40]. Concerning the intrinsic properties of thorium and uranium oxides as promising catalysts for OCM it should be said that thorium oxide has itself properties that favors the OCM reaction, such as: (1) p-type conductor at high temperature [35], (2) high rate of oxygen exchange [37], (3) basic oxide and stable oxidation state (Th4+) [41] and (4) Th4+ is easily substituted by other ions with approximately the same ionic radius, such as alkaline earth metals, which creates defects (ion vacancies) and enhance its p type conductivity [35]. On the other hand, uranium oxides are rather attractive for catalysis as their stoichiometry can be varied in a wide range. The valence state of uranium can be also easily changed depending on temperature and oxygen to uranium ratio (O/U) [42], making uranium-containing catalysts active for the partial oxidation of methane [43–46]. Herein, we report for the first time the study of the oxidative coupling of methane using N2O as oxidant over bimetallic calcium–actinide oxides. The goal is the production of C2 hydrocarbons (ethane and ethylene) and the study of the influence of actinide phase on the catalysts behavior. The novelty of this work lies on these purposes. All catalysts were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy–energy dispersive X-ray detection (SEM-EDS) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) for structural characterization, temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) and oxidative dehydrogenation/dehydration of 2-propanol for acid–base characterization. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Catalysts were prepared by sol-gel reaction accordingly to the Pechini method as described elsewhere [47]. An aqueous solution of stoichiometric amounts of metal nitrates (calcium nitrate pentahydrate, purity 98.0%; actinide nitrate pentahydrate or hexahydrate (An=Th and U), purity 99%), in the presence of citric acid (purity 99.5%) and ethylene glycol (purity 99.5%), was mixed and heated at ≈80°C giving a porous gel that was dried with acetonitrile and afterwards calcined at 900°C for 5h under dry air. All the reagents were used without further purification. The molar ratio between calcium nitrate and actinide nitrates was 0.5; described in the literature as the best ratio for high conversion and selectivity into hydrocarbons [48]. The calcium nitrate and actinide nitrate were mixed with citric acid (calcium: actinide: citric acid molar ratio of 1:2:3) and ethylene glycol was added to achieve a molar ratio of 2:3 with the citric acid. It should be said that thorium and uranium nitrates used in this work are highly depleted and no measurable radioactivity was detected. 2.2 Catalysts characterization The XRD patterns were obtained in reflection geometry with a PANanalitycal X’Pert Pro diffractometer using Cu Kα monochromatic radiation (λ =1.5406Å). The operational settings for all scans were: voltage=45kV; current=40mA; 2θ scan range 5–80° using a step size of 0.03° at a scan speed of 0.02°/min. For identification purposes, the relative intensities (I/I 0) and the d-spacing (Å) were compared with standard JCPDS powder diffraction files [49]. In CO2-TPD study, carbon dioxide controlled adsorption/desorption study was used to determine the catalysts basicity. Before measurements, all catalysts (≈20mg) were saturated with CO2 (20mLmin−1) at 50°C for 1h, followed by cleaning with a pure He stream (50mLmin−1) at the saturation temperature for 3h. Once a stable line was obtained, chemisorbed CO2 was desorbed by heating from 50°C up to 1000°C at a rate of 10°Cmin−1 and the desorption monitored by gas chromatography using a Shimadzu Mod. 9A equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD; T column =105°C, T detector =105°C, 150mA). The catalysts acid–base properties were also evaluate by the study of the oxidative dehydrogenation/dehydration of 2-propanol (a different molecular probe). The catalytic activity tests for the oxidative dehydrogenation/dehydration of 2-propanol were carried out in a U-shaped quartz reactor (plug-flow type), with a quartz frit and an inside volume of 15cm3, operating continuously at atmospheric pressure under a gaseous flow of 0.75% of alcohol in air (N2/O2:80/20 v%, Air Liquide K, purity 99.9995%) as described elsewhere [50]. The surface morphology and the particle size of the samples were obtained using a FE-SEM JEOL JSM-6500F, operating at 15–20keV and 80μA. The chemical composition was determined by coupled EDS system. TEM was performed using a Hitachi model H8100, with LaB6 filament, operating at 200kV. 2.3 Catalytic experiments The oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) was carried out at atmospheric pressure in a fixed-bed U-shaped quartz reactor, plug-flow countercurrent type reactor, with a quartz frit and an inside volume of 15cm3. Mass flow controllers were used to control CH4 (Air Liquide, purity 99.9995%), N2O (Air Liquide, purity 99.9995%) or O2/N2 (20/80, v/v Air Liquide, purity 99.9995%) and He (Air Liquide, purity 99.9995%) flows. A thermocouple was placed on the catalytic bed for continuous monitoring of the sample temperature. Unless otherwise stated, a gaseous mixture of CH4 (3%), N2O (3%) and He (94%) was introduced and the reaction studied with an adequate Gas Hourly Space Velocity (GHSV) of 8500mL of CH4/g of catalysts (m =20mg) at 750°C. When using oxygen as oxidant, the gaseous mixture has 3, 3, 12 and 82% of CH4, O2, N2 and He, respectively. The specific areas of the various catalysts were measured but, in all cases they are very similar (1m2/g). As such, the differences in the catalysts activity and behavior could not be attributed to differences in the catalysts surface areas. In all described cases the compositions were analyzed on-line as described elsewhere [44,51,52]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts activity and selectivity The bimetallic calcium–actinide (Th and U) oxides were active and selective for the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) using N2O as oxidant. The results were compared with those obtained over pure metal oxides. Fig. 1 shows the catalytic behavior of CaO and bimetallic Ca–An (An=Th and U) oxides. The trend of evolution obtained over pure actinide oxides (ThO2, and UO3) is similar to that of CaO. In the temperature range studied (650–800°C) and for a CH4/N2O molar ratio of 1, the reaction main products were primarily C2 hydrocarbons (C2H4 and C2H6); particularly over the bimetallic calcium–thorium oxide catalyst (e.g. CH4 conversion≈28%; C2 selectivity≈53%; C2 yield≈15% at 800°C, see Fig. 1A). In some cases C3 hydrocarbons were also detected but the percentage was always very low (<2%). It is also noticed that the catalytic performance changes significantly with the reagents partial pressure on gaseous stream. Fig. 1B shows the results obtained at 750°C for different CH4/N2O ratios. The activity and selectivity seems to achieve a steady state for CH4/N2O≥1. This value (CH4/N2O=1) was selected as standard experimental condition for further studies. The increase of CH4/N2O molar ratio (decrease of N2O concentration on the gaseous stream) leads to a decrease of O2 concentration on the gaseous stream due to N2O decomposition that inhibits the conversion of methane. On the other hand, it is well known from others selective oxidation studies with light (C1–C4) hydrocarbons that products selectivity is a function of the degree of hydrocarbon conversion: selectivity toward C2 hydrocarbons is usually high at low CH4 conversions, but decreases with an increase in the conversion [53]. The catalytic performance seems also clearly dependent of the actinide phase properties. An evaluation of the results obtained at 750°C and at CH4 isoconversion (≈15±3%) shows selectivities to C2 hydrocarbons that are very different (≈64% and 32% over the bimetallic Ca–Th and Ca–U oxide catalysts, respectively) and favorable to the bimetallic calcium–thorium oxide catalyst (Fig. 1 and Table 1 ). One possible explanation lies on the known and superior reducible character of the uranium oxide phase, especially when compared to that of the thorium oxide phase [54,55]. The reducible character of the uranium oxide phase favors the formation of oxidation products. Additionally, both actinide oxides have properties such as basicity strength and conductivity that are completely different [35,54,56]. In the literature, reports about OCM over actinide based oxide catalysts are scarce and the few ones that exist describes only the behavior of thorium or uranium based catalysts using oxygen as oxidant agent [35–40,46,57]. To the best of our knowledge, there are no reports of OCM studies performed over actinide or actinide based oxides using N2O as oxidizing agent. Table 1 shows a compilation of the results available in the literature together with those obtained in this work under either O2 or N2O. The entries without reference correspond to values obtained in the present study. Clearly, the best results for the production of C2 hydrocarbons are those obtained with N2O over CaO and the bimetallic calcium – thorium oxide catalysts. For both, the C2 yield (≈15%) is comparable to the best results reported so far in the literatures over thorium based catalysts using O2 as oxidant. This is a remarkable and somehow unexpected result. It is know that the catalysts are in general more active under O2 and Kondratenko et al. [11,13] established that the substitution of O2 by N2O gives rise to an increasing in the selectivity to C2 hydrocarbons but, the conversion of methane is an order of magnitude greater under O2. Ulyana Zavyalova et al. [58] have made a statistical analysis of published OCM catalytic data and have shown that the maximal C2 selectivities under O2 range from 72 to 82% and the respective C2 yields range from 16 to 26%. Therefore, our results open up a brand new strategy for developing OCM highly efficient catalysts based on f block elements with much improved performance under N2O. To explain the difference in the catalysts performance using either O2 or N2O we must take into account the mechanism and the different oxygen species generated from these two oxidizing agents. The superior selectivity to hydrocarbons under N2O is normally associated to the no formation of peroxo species (e.g. O2 2−, O2 −) [59]. These species are considered essential for the formation of oxidation products (CO, CO2) and are suppressed in the absence of O2 in the gas-phase [59]. On the other hand, the importance of O− species in the OCM reaction has been repeatedly highlighted by Lunsford and co-workers [18,60]. These monoatomic oxygen species are the dominant species formed from N2O activation and are responsible for the selective conversion of CH4 to C2H6 via formation of CH3 radicals [59,61]. Furthermore, the nature of oxygen species is different over reducible and non-reducible oxide matrix. Lattice oxygen (O2−) species are normally associated with reducible metal oxides. On the contrary, due to a significantly higher band gap in non-reducible oxide matrix, differently charged oxygen species (e.g. O− and O2 −) can exist on the catalyst surface, namely over the thorium catalyst, which could explain the formation of hydrocarbons [13,59]. In the case of the uranium catalyst, the dominant formation of oxidation products seen is expected due to its reducible nature. 3.2 Catalysts characterization XRD analyses were performed on fresh and used catalysts. The patterns before reaction are consistent with those of standard ThO2 (cubic phase) and UO3 (hexagonal phase) as reported on the standard JCPDS powder diffraction files [49] (Fig. 2 ). CaO diffraction patterns were not observed (represented in the XRD spectrum by dashed lines), but this is a quite common result for calcium bimetallic compounds solid solutions [35]. After reaction at 800°C, the intensity of the diffraction patterns decrease significantly and any new phase was not observed. For both bimetallic Ca–An (An=Th, U) oxides the assignment correspond to ThO2 and UO3 phases. Lattice parameter shifts were not observed. This fact can be due to the small differences in ionic radii of Ca2+ (1.12Å) when compared to Th4+ (1.05Å) or U6+ (0.86Å). Therefore, we cannot exclude the incorporation of the CaO into the lattices of the actinide oxides. Nevertheless, it is believed that these systems are better described as CaO embedded in a matrix of actinide oxides. Fig. 3 shows the SEM images of Ca–Th–O and Ca–U–O of fresh catalysts were a solid state sponge type structure can be visualized. The SEM analysis shows a catalysts morphology better described as a homogeneous solution of calcium oxide and actinide oxide (see inserts) and the EDS analysis confirmed the expected atomic ratios between calcium and actinide on all synthesized catalysts (Ca/An found: ∼0.41±0.18 and ∼0.48±0.03 for An=U and Th, respectively; Ca/An expected: 0.5 for An=U and Th). SEM was also performed on the samples after the catalytic reactions. No changes on the morphology neither in the expected atomic ratios between calcium and actinide were observed (figure not shown). Particles size were estimated from XRD line broadening using the Scherrer's equation [62] and ThO2 (111) and UO3 (100) reflections. The medium particles size before and after reaction is very similar and on the range of 18–20nm, showing no significant variation. In order to have a better idea of the distribution of the catalysts particles size, TEM measurements were performed (Fig. 4 ). It was seen that the average particles size was 2±1nm and 7±2nm for the for the Ca–Th–O and Ca–U–O nanoparticles, respectively. Despite of the fact that in both systems the average particles size value is smaller than 10nm, it is interesting to notice that the highest selectivity to C2 hydrocarbons was measured over the catalyst (Ca–Th–O) that presents the smallest average particles size. It is known that catalysts acid–base properties can be related to their activity, namely to the formation of CH3 radicals that are relevant for the production of C2 hydrocarbons [17–20]. Therefore, the characterization of the catalysts surface acid–base properties allows a better understanding of their catalytic behavior. As such, CO2-TPD was used to study the basicity of our samples. This study was complemented by the study of their behavior for the oxidative dehydrogenation/dehydration of 2-propanol. The use of this molecular probe to study different materials acid–base properties is a well-established method [63–65]. Fig. 5 shows the CO2-TPD profiles obtained. The basic sites were classified as low and medium strength (T m below 500°C) and high strength sites (T m over 500°C) according to the different carbon dioxide maximum rate desorption temperatures, T m. Its density distribution was measured from the area under the CO2-TPD profiles. Table 2 shows the results obtained in terms of strength and quantity of basic sites and includes also the results for oxidative dehydrogenation/dehydration of 2-propanol. For correlation purposes, the best OCM results obtained at 750°C were also included. CO2-TPD highest number of basic sites was measured over CaO and Ca–Th–O, whereas the lowest numbers of basic sites were measured over UO3 and Ca–U–O. The result obtained over ThO2 was a complete surprise since its basic nature is a known and well established fact [41]. However, the values reported in the literature are very low (0.36mmol CO2/g cat [41] or 0.273mmol de CO2/g cat [35], especially when compared to those measured in this work and probably lower than our TCD limit of detection (≈0.4mmol CO2/g cat) which could explain the ThO2 apparent inconsistency. The results obtained with 2-propanol as a molecular probe, confirm the trend of CO2-TPD study and the relative low basicity of ThO2. Indeed, the selectivity to the dehydration product (propene) depends mainly on acidic nature of the materials, but it is also influenced by its amphoteric nature [63–65]. Therefore, the bimetallic calcium–actinide oxide catalysts OCM differences in terms of selectivity correlate with the differences in terms of surface basicity: higher basicity implies higher selectivity to hydrocarbons (Fig. 6 ). It can be said that the catalytic performance dependent on the actinide phase properties and follow OCM established rules in terms of acid–base properties [9]. One possible justification can be found on the reduction potential of the metals. As we said before, uranium compounds usually have a higher reduction potential than thorium, which enhance the formation of oxidation products [54]. On the other hand, it is also known that beyond the basicity and acidity of the catalysts, the electrical proprieties (i.e. n- and/or p-type of conductivity) are important factors that affect the activity and selectivity of oxidative coupling of methane catalysts [28]. Alkaline earth oxides (CaO, SrO, BaO, MgO) and rare earth oxides (e.g., Sm2O3, La2O3) are essentially p-type conductors. Pure ThO2 is a high temperature p-type conductor. In the past it was suggested a relationship between p-type conductivity and OCM catalytic performance [66,67], since these materials are good OCM catalysts. On other hand, the n-type conductor oxides are poor OCM catalysts, (e.g. CeO2, Pr2O3, Tb2O3) [28,68,69]. UO3 is n-type conductor [56,70]. As such, the results obtained in this work over ThO2, Ca–Th–O and CaO, on one side, and UO3 and Ca–U–O, on the other side (as showed in Table 1) can be explained by the above described characteristics. However, further studies on electrical conducting properties are needed in order to confirm such hypothesis. 4 Conclusion Bimetallic calcium–actinide oxides (An=Th, U) were prepared by sol–gel (Pechini method) and for the first time tested for the oxidative coupling of methane using nitrous oxide as oxidant. The reaction main products were hydrocarbons and the best results were those obtained at 750°C over the bimetallic calcium–thorium oxide (C2+ selectivity>60%). The catalytic performance is dependent of the actinide properties and the main factor that seems to contribute to the variation of the activity and selectivity along the actinide series are their acid–base and electrical transport properties. coredata.dc:description: New bimetallic calcium–actinide (Th and U) oxides were synthesized and tested as catalysts for the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) using nitrous oxide as oxidant. The reaction main products were primarily C2 hydrocarbons (C2H4 and C2H6), particularly over the bimetallic calcium–thorium oxide catalyst (CH4 conversion≈28%; C2 selectivity≈53%; C2 yield≈15% at 800°C). The selectivity to hydrocarbons is promoted when thorium replaces uranium on the bimetallic calcium–actinide oxides (at CH4 isoconversion=15±3%; C2 selectivity≈32% and 64% over the bimetallic Ca–U–O and Ca–Th–O catalysts at 750°C, respectively), which can be linked to the actinide oxide phase properties. The bimetallic calcium–actinide oxides catalytic performance correlates with their acid–base and conductivity properties (selectivity to hydrocarbons increases with the catalysts basicity and it is higher over p-type conductors, e.g. ThO2). The influence of the reaction temperature, gas phase CH4/N2O molar ratio and type of oxidant agent were also studied. In particular, the studies performed either under O2 or N2O confirm that the use of nitrous oxide improves the selectivity to hydrocarbons. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time that an OCM study using N2O as oxidant agent is reported over bimetallic Ca–An (An=Th and U) oxides aiming the production of C2 hydrocarbons.
coredata.dc:title: Light hydrocarbons production over bimetallic calcium–actinide oxide catalysts using N2O as oxidant
